abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the National Roads
            Project for Lebanon were the following: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that when
            implementing large road rehabilitation programs, especially
            those with roads passing through densely populated areas, or
            which have substantial geotechnical and topographical
            challenges, it is critical that the implementing agency have
            sufficient in-house capacity to prepare, design and
            supervise works. For complex road rehabilitation programs,
            greater emphasis should be placed on assessing the
            conditions at individual project sites, rather than trying
            to finalize detailed designs. The delivery of diagnostic
            mechanisms and tools to strengthen a road
            administration's capacity to evaluate road programs
            should be developed in the early stages of project
            implementation for their potential demonstration effect.
            Bank funding for ambitious and far-reaching reforms is most
            effective when undertaken to support and deepen on going
            restructuring schemes that are Government-initiated. When
            resorting to special units to manage projects, they should
            always to located within the agency/entity that will
            ultimately be responsible for sustaining the project after
            the closing date. Operations developed in post-conflict
            situations should be open to corrections amid emerging
            realities on the ground. Project teams should also be aware
            that re-establishing a credible procurement process in
            post-conflict environments is a necessary and critical
            first-step for most governments, and that it may take
            considerable time before a local system is harmonized and functional.
